title: Analyzing archaeological data using R
text:
Welcome to AES_707 Statistics seminar for archaeology students at the Department of Archaeology and Museology, Masaryk University. The course is taught by Petr Pajdla and Peter Tkáč.
Information given here applies to spring semester 2024, the page will be continuously updated throughout the semester. The course was taught also in 2022 and 2020.

title: Analyzing archaeological data using R
text:
Information on assessment
To pass the course, you have to finish and submit a report on your project.

title: Title of your project
text: This is a template for a report on your project. As you already know, we expect you to work on an analysis of a data set of your choice and hand in a report similar to this one. Delete the following examples as soon as you will be sure what you are doing. The suggested structure of a report is below. Delete anything you do not need, feel free to edit the document.

title: Title of your project
text:
R Markdown
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00

title: Title of your project
text:
Including Plots
You can also embed plots, for example:





Note that the echo = FALSE parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

Abstract
Write a short and comprehensive abstract for your project (one paragraph of text).

Keywords
Include several relevant keywords.

title: Title of your project
text:
Introduction
Write what data set you are analyzing and why, what is your goal and so on (one paragraph).
Also load all the packages you will be using in your analysis here.

# put your library calls in here
library(ggplot2)


Data
Briefly introduce your data set. Where does it come from? What does it contain? Load your data here and use any handy functions you learned to show what the variable names are, how big your data are, what data types does it contain etc.

# read your data set here
# remember, this # is a comment (ctrl+shift+c)
# data <- read.csv("")

Try to answer following questions using code:

How many variables are there?
How many rows does the data set have?
What are the names of the variables?
What data types are there in the data set?


# str(data) and other functions you learned...

title: Title of your project
text:
Exploratory analysis

Qualitative variables
Are there any qualitative variables in your data set? Choose at least one and answer these questions if possible:

How many values does your qualitative variable has?
Show the count of values of the chosen qualitative variable in a suitable plot.


#  show us some plots...
# ggplot(data, aes(...)) +
#   geom_bar()



Quantitative variables
Explore your quantitative variables. Plot the distribution of the variables. Show us a histogram or a density plot. Try to compare the quantities in several groups using a box plot…
Give us numeric summaries of the chosen quantitative variable:

What is the mean and standard deviation?
What is the median and IQR?

How does the distribution of the quantitative variable look? Is it a normal distribution? Is it right/left-skewed? Is it multimodal? Try to prove these points with both the graphs and a hypothesis test.


Data transformation challenge
Use at least three functions (filter, select, group_by, summarise, arrange, mutate) from the dplyr package to transform your data and again show some summary statistics, plots and so on. Be creative!

title: Title of your project
text:
Multivariate exploration

Will be added…

title: Organizing data
text:
Assignments

Read Karl Broman’s guide on how to organize data in spreadsheets.
As an article: Broman, K. W. and Woo, K. H. 2017: Data Organization in Spreadsheets. The American Statistician 72(1): 2–10, DOI: https://doi.org/gdz6cm.
Read chapter Data in Quantitative analysis in archaeology book by VanPool and Leonard (2011).

title: Course introduction
text:
Assignments

Read chapters Quantifying Archaeology in Quantitative Analysis in Archaeology book by VanPool, T. L. and Leonard, R. D. (2011).
Optionally, read Introductions in:

Quantifying archaeology book by Stephen Shennan, and/or
Quantitative Methods in Archaeology book by David L. Carlson (see Resources for details). These give a general overview on why to use quantitative/computational methods in archaeology.

title: Coding in R
text:
Prerequisites

Go through R Basics tutorials here.

title: Coding in R
text: Exercises

title: Coding in R
text:
Assignments

Find a suitable dataset for your Project.

title: Project
text: To pass the course you will have to work on a small project. Group/pair cooperation is possible, but each student has to submit their own report on the analysis. There are two options, you can choose to work either on your own dataset or use an existing published data.

title: Project
text:
Get the data
Although the first step in most of the analysis would be creating the research question(s), we assume our questions and goals are already set and skip to the step where we get the data suitable to answer our questions…

Working with your own dataset

You can choose to use your own data. This is especially useful if you are working on your BA/MA/PhD thesis or an article and want to analyze the data collected for the given work.
This option is easier because you probably know what your dataset contains and what each variable means, how it was collected etc.



Using an existing dataset

Find a suitable dataset online, scrape a website, get it in a book, anything that comes to mind, be creative. Bear in mind that the dataset needs to contain a mixture of quantitative and qualitative variables. It can be organized as a table, then the work is easier for you. If it is a database, we can give you a hand with data preparation etc.
We recommend to look in the Journal of Open Archaeology Data. Datasets published here have clear use conditions (license), are deposited in a suitable repository and should be well documented.
If you choose to use a dataset you found anywhere else (or web scraped etc.) please make sure that it is easily accessible and suitable for the analysis.

title: Project
text:
Get to know the data

Make sure you know where your data is and how is it stored (format and how to read it into R).
Make sure you know what each variable means, what type of data does it contain etc.
The dataset should contain at least several quantitative and qualitative variables in order for you to be able to practice creating visualizations.


Report template
RMarkdown template for the project report is here. Create a new RMarkdown file (.Rmd), copy and paste the contents of the template in your file, do your changes, write your report and push the Knit button. Follow the instructions in the template to work on your project.


How to submit the report
Feel free to contact us if you need any help or assistance during the work on your project. Simply send us both the source Rmd file and the HTML output with your questions and we will address the problem either directly or in class.

title: Resources
text: Here is a non exhaustive list of resources and links we find useful. These cover various topics and most are openly available online. We expect you to be creative and search (not only) through these resources if you get stuck with your project or find any topics difficult to understand. If you find it hard to get access to any of the articles or books mentioned here, do not hesitate contacting us. Definitely do not use websites like Sci-Hub or Library Genesis that seem to provide scientific knowledge to all. The King of the Potato People prohibits this.

title: Resources
text:
Quantitative and digital archaeology

Carlson, D. L. 2017: Quantitative Methods in Archaeology Using R. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
VanPool, TL and Leonard, RD. 2011. Quantitative analysis in archaeology. Chichester: Wiley-Blackwell.
Drennan, R. D. 2010: Statistics for Archaeologists: A common sense approach. New York: Springer.
Baxter, M. 2003: Statistics in Archaeology. London: Wiley.
Fletcher, M., Lock, G. R. 1994: Digging Numbers: Elementary statistics for archaeologists. Oxford: Oxbow.
Shennan, S. 1988: Quantifying Archaeology. Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press.

title: Resources
text:
R programming language and environment

R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham, Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel and Garrett Grolemund (2nd Ed.).
Data Visualization. A practical introduction by Kieran Healy.
CRAN Task View is a list of R packages useful in archaeology maintained by Ben Marwick. There is also a list of articles using R in the analysis with data and code published.


Where to look for help

Posit/RStudio cheatsheets, especially data visualization, transformation, tidying and import cheatsheets will come in useful.
Search through Stack Overflow. Find some tips on asking good questions and providing minimal reproducible examples in this thread.

title: Resources
text:
Reproducibility

Marwick, B. 2017: Computational Reproducibility in Archaeological Research: Basic Principles and a Case Study of Their Implementation. Journal of Archaeological Method and Theory 24(2): 424–450. DOI: 10.1007/s10816-015-9272-9.
Marwick, B., Boettiger, C. and Mullen, L. 2018: Packaging Data Analytical Work Reproducibly Using R (and Friends). The American Statistician 72(1): 80–88. DOI: 10.1080/00031305.2017.1375986.


Data management

Karl Broman’s guide on how to organize data in spreadsheets. The same as an article, DOI: https://doi.org/gdz6cm.
Jenny Bryan’s slides on naming things.
Hadley Wickham’s paper on tidy data, DOI: https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v059.i10.



RMarkdown/Quarto and scientific writing

British Ecological Society has a nice series of Guides to Better Science covering various topics including Reproducible Code and Data Management.
A short guide by Ben Marwick on how to setup Atom (this could be any text editor) and Zotero (citation management software).
The Plain Person’s Guide to Plain Text Social Science by Kieran Healy.

title: Resources
section: R as a GIS and spatial analysis
text:
R as a GIS and spatial analysis

Geocomputation with R book by Robin Lovelace, Jakub Nowosad, and Jannes Muenchow.

title: Resources
text:
Other links and tools

Open-archaeo is a list of open source archaeological software and resources maintained by Zack Batist.
